titleStmt.title: Nathaniel Wolfe to James F. Robinson
CWG8861

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, James F. Robinson: Governor's Official Correspondence File, Petitions for Pardons, Remissions, and Respites, 1862-1863

body.p:
Mr John O Ross a respectable citizen of Jefferson County had a little difficulty with a citizen of Louisville in which he struck a blow with his fist once, inflicting no injury of any consequence. He was indicted in the Police Court of Louisville and was fined fifty dollars -- He used no weapon and as I have stated no injury of any consequence was done. He has paid to the Man that of the Court thirty five dollars & 25/100, the costs and the amount to which the atto for Commth is ^in the letter^ He now asks at your hands a remission of the remainder and if you should decline to grant it, he trusts you will give a respite. His affairs are
very much embarrassed and he feels himself unable to pay the balance of the execution at this time

I hope you will grant his request
Very respy
Yr obt servt
Nat. Wolfe
P. S. The style of this case is Commth vs J O Ross. The execution is now in the hands of the Marshall. It is a capias pro fine
N. Wolfe of Louisville asks remission of fine of Mr. O Ross
Respite for six months granted sent to Mr Wolfe

J F Robinson
$50 } Mis.
Issd June 19 1863
